defs.docs:
log4rs is a highly configurable logging framework modeled after Java's
 Logback and log4j libraries.

attributes.value: ! log4rs is a highly configurable logging framework modeled after Java's
! The basic units of configuration are *appenders*, *encoders*, *filters*, and
! An appender takes a log record and logs it somewhere, for example, to a
! file, the console, or the syslog.
! An encoder is responsible for taking a log record, transforming it into the
! appropriate output format, and writing it out. An appender will normally
! Filters are associated with appenders and, like the name would suggest,
! filter log events coming into that appender.
! A log event is targeted at a specific logger, which are identified by
! string names. The logging macros built in to the `log` crate set the logger
! of a log event to the one identified by the module containing the
! Loggers form a hierarchy: logger names are divided into components by "::".
! One logger is the ancestor of another if the first logger's component list
! is a prefix of the second logger's component list.
! Loggers are associated with a maximum log level. Log events for that logger
! with a level above the maximum will be ignored. The maximum log level for
! any logger can be configured manually; if it is not, the level will be
! Loggers are also associated with a set of appenders. Appenders can be
! associated directly with a logger. In addition, the appenders of the
! logger's parent will be associated with the logger unless the logger has
! its *additivity* set to `false`. Log events sent to the logger that are not
! filtered out by the logger's maximum log level will be sent to all
! The "root" logger is the ancestor of all other loggers. Since it has no
! ancestors, its additivity cannot be configured.
! log4rs can be configured programmatically by using the builders in the
! `config` module to construct a log4rs `Config` object, which can be passed
! The more common configuration method, however, is via a separate config
! file. The `init_file` function takes the path to a config file as
! well as a `Deserializers` object which is responsible for instantiating the
! various objects specified by the config file. The `file` module
! documentation covers the exact configuration syntax, but an example in the
! log4rs makes heavy use of Cargo features to enable consumers to pick the
! functionality they wish to use. File-based configuration requires the `file`
! feature, and each file format requires its own feature as well. In addition,
! each component has its own feature. For example, YAML support requires the
! `yaml_format` feature and the console appender requires the
! As a convenience, the `all_components` feature activates all logger components.
! # Scan this file for changes every 30 seconds
!   # An appender named "stdout" that writes to stdout
!   # An appender named "requests" that writes to a file with a custom pattern encoder
! # Set the default logging level to "warn" and attach the "stdout" appender to the root
!   # Raise the maximum log level for events sent to the "app::backend::db" logger to "info"
!   # Route log events sent to the "app::requests" logger to the "requests" appender,
!   # and *not* the normal appenders installed at the root
!     // use handle to change logger configuration at runtime

defs.name: append
defs.docs: Determines if the appender will append to or truncate the output file.

attributes.value: / Determines if the appender will append to or truncate the output file.
/ # The path of the log file. Required.
/ # Specifies if the appender should append to or truncate the log file if it
/ # The encoder to use to format output. Defaults to `kind: pattern`.
! Logging directly to a file can be a dangerous proposition for long running
! processes. You wouldn't want to start a server up and find out a couple
! weeks later that the disk is filled with hundreds of gigabytes of logs! A
! rolling file appender alleviates these issues by limiting the amount of log
! Like a normal file appender, a rolling file appender is configured with the
! location of its log file and the encoder which formats log events written
! to it. In addition, it holds a "policy" object which controls when a log
! file is rolled over and how the old files are archived.
! For example, you may configure an appender to roll the log over once it
! reaches 50 megabytes, and to preserve the last 10 log files.

defs.name: FixedWindowRoller
defs.docs: A roller which maintains a fixed window of archived log files.

attributes.value: / A roller which maintains a fixed window of archived log files.
/ A `FixedWindowRoller` is configured with a filename pattern, a base index,
/ and a maximum file count. Each archived log file is associated with a numeric
/ index ordering it by age, starting at the base index. Archived log files are
/ named by substituting all instances of `{}` with the file's index in the
/ For example, if the filename pattern is `archive/foo.{}.log`, the base index
/ is 0 and the count is 2, the first log file will be archived as
/ `archive/foo.0.log`. When the next log file is archived, `archive/foo.0.log`
/ will be renamed to `archive/foo.1.log` and the new log file will be named
/ `archive/foo.0.log`. When the third log file is archived,
/ `archive/foo.1.log` will be deleted, `archive/foo.0.log` will be renamed to
/ `archive/foo.1.log`, and the new log file will be renamed to
/ If the file extension of the pattern is `.gz` and the `gzip` Cargo feature
/ is enabled, the archive files will be gzip-compressed.
/ Note that this roller will have to rename every archived file every time the
/ log rolls over. Performance may be negatively impacted by specifying a large

/ # The maximum number of archived logs to maintain. Required.
/ # The base value for archived log indices. Defaults to 0.

attributes.value: / An `Encode`r which writes a JSON object.

defs.name: new
defs.docs: Returns a new `JsonEncoder` with a default configuration.

attributes.value: / Returns a new `JsonEncoder` with a default configuration.
! The pattern syntax is similar to Rust's string formatting syntax. It
! consists of raw text interspersed with format arguments. The grammar is:
! The `{`, `}`, `(`, `)`, and `\` characters are part of the pattern syntax;
! they must be escaped to appear in output. Like with Rust's string
! formatting syntax, type the character twice to escape it. That is, `{{`
! will be rendered as `{` in output and `))` will be rendered as `)`.
! In addition, these characters may also be escaped by prefixing them with a
! `\` character. That is, `\{` will be rendered as `{`.
! A formatter inserts a dynamic portion of text into the pattern. It may be
! text derived from a log event or from some other context like the current
! time. Formatters may be passed arguments consisting of parenthesized format
! The following formatters are currently supported. Unless otherwise stated,
! a formatter does not accept any argument.
! * `d`, `date` - The current time. By default, the ISO 8601 format is used.
!     A custom format may be provided in the syntax accepted by `chrono`.
!     The timezone defaults to local, but can be specified explicitly by
!     passing a second argument of `utc` for UTC or `local` for local time.
! * `f`, `file` - The source file that the log message came from, or `???` if
! * `h`, `highlight` - Styles its argument according to the log level. The
!     style is intense red for errors, red for warnings, blue for info, and
!     the default style for all other levels.
! the level is ERROR
! * `L`, `line` - The line that the log message came from, or `???` if not
! * `M`, `module` - The module that the log message came from, or `???` if not
! * `t`, `target` - The target of the log message.
! * `T`, `thread` - The name of the current thread.
! * `I`, `thread_id` - The ID of the current thread.
! * `X`, `mdc` - A value from the [MDC][MDC]. The first argument specifies
!     the key, and the second argument specifies the default value if the
!     key is not present in the MDC. The second argument is optional, and
! * An "unnamed" formatter simply formats its argument, applying the format
! The format specification determines how the output of a formatter is
! The fill and alignment values are used in conjunction with a minimum width
! value (see below) to control the behavior when a formatter's output is less
! than the minimum. While the default behavior is to pad the output to the
! right with space characters (i.e. left align it), the fill value specifies
! the character used, and the alignment value is one of:
! * `<` - Left align by appending the fill character to the formatter output
! * `>` - Right align by prepending the fill character to the formatter
! By default, the full contents of a formatter's output will be inserted into
! the pattern output, but both the minimum and maximum lengths can be
! configured. Any output over the maximum length will be truncated, and
! output under the minimum length will be padded (see above).
! The default pattern is `{d} {l} {t} - {m}{n}` which produces output like
! The pattern `{m:>10.15}` will right-align the log message to a minimum of
! 10 bytes, filling in with space characters, and truncate output after 15
! bytes. The message `hello` will therefore be displayed as
! hello, while the message `hello there, world!` will be
! The pattern `{({l} {m}):15.15}` will output the log level and message
! limited to exactly 15 bytes, padding with space characters on the right if
! necessary. The message `hello` and log level `INFO` will be displayed as
! INFO hello , while the message `hello, world!` and log
! level `DEBUG` will be truncated to `DEBUG hello, wo`.

defs.name: file
defs.docs: Support for log4rs configuration from files.

attributes.value: ! Support for log4rs configuration from files.
! Multiple file formats are supported, each requiring a Cargo feature to be
! enabled. YAML support requires the `yaml_format` feature, JSON support requires
! the `json_format` feature, and TOML support requires the `toml_format` feature.
! All file formats currently share the same structure. The example below is
! # If set, log4rs will scan the file at the specified rate for changes and
! # automatically reconfigure the logger. The input string is parsed by the
! # The "appenders" map contains the set of appenders, indexed by their names.
!     # All appenders must specify a "kind", which will be used to look up the
!     # logic to construct the appender in the `Deserializers` passed to the
!     # Filters attached to an appender are specified inside the "filters"
!         # Like appenders, filters are identified by their "kind".
!         # The remainder of the configuration is passed along to the
!         # filter's builder, and will vary based on the kind of filter.
!     # The remainder of the configuration is passed along to the appender's
!     # builder, and will vary based on the kind of appender.
!     # Appenders will commonly be associated with an encoder.
!       # Like appenders, encoders are identified by their "kind".
!       # The remainder of the configuration is passed along to the
!       # encoder's builder, and will vary based on the kind of encoder.
! # The root logger is configured by the "root" map.
!   # The maximum log level for the root logger.
!   # The list of appenders attached to the root logger.
! # The "loggers" map contains the set of configured loggers, indexed by their
!     # The list of appenders attached to the logger.
!     # The additivity of the logger. If true, appenders attached to the logger's
!     # parent will also be attached to this logger.
